p:
The volumetric and dynamical properties of the 1° site revealed in our simulations suggest that NA can bind many structurally distinct and complex sialoglycan receptors as part of the host-cell recognition process. Indeed, human glycans are vastly diverse in both their sugar composition and configuration (e.g., long, short, biantennary, triantennary, etc.).
64 As such, the transient deepening and broadening of the 1° NA site may allow the glycoprotein to accommodate bulkier (e.g., long, bi/triantennary) and longer glycan receptors. Given that our simulations model the entire viral envelope, it may be that full-pocket opening only occurs in a crowded viral-surface environment. Alternatively, our simulations may capture full-pocket opening because the viral coat includes many replicates of individual glycoproteins, enabling extensive conformational sampling.
